Key Arguments: The proposed legislation is based on naive assumptions about digital platforms and civic discourse.
Digital platforms are not solely dominated by institutions with asymmetric power; individuals also use them for civic discourse.
The bill wrongly equates individual civic discourse with institutional media discourse.
Legal actions against individuals for civic discourse are not comparable to actions against institutions.
The requirement for recording and personal identification in online discourse contradicts offline realities.
No government body should be the final arbiter of truth in civic discourse.
Notable Quotes: The bill in question is as supremely naive as it is foolish, and it is founded on a premise so fundamentally misinformed justice would be ill served to deem this as irony.
If one is sincerely concerned about the wellbeing of Australians, our democracy, society and economy, kill this bill with all haste.
